summary: First, we study the characteristics of asymmetric phase shifts and co-movement of industrial production cycles. Then we check the spectral causality of these cycles with various policy variables, which enabled us to explore the non-linear structure of the economy by computing Granger Causality for each frequency separately.
title: Disaggregated Indian Industrial Cycles: A spectral analysis

summary: We investigate the indirect impact of globalization on job quality (workforce composition) through changes in product market structure for the Indian formal manufacturing industries. We found that the firms responded to greater product market competition due to globalization by hiring relatively more contract workers. It enabled them to achieve labor market flexibility.
title: Globalization and Worker Composition in Indian Formal manufacturing: New Evidence on Product Market Competition Channel

summary: We conducted a primary survey of five urban slums in Kolkata to document their socio-economic pattern and living standards. While the slums mostly suffer from a lack of the necessary infrastructure and facilities (like the provision of hygienic toilet facilities), there are some development and modernization signs.
title: Slums in Kolkata: A Socio-economic analysis

summary: We use textual analysis algorithm to uncover that when imports are affected by per-shipment compliance costs created by non-tariff trade barriers, it will have a sizeable direct welfare effect on the economy.
title: The Compliance Costs of Non-Tariff Measures: Measurement, Theory, and Policy

We are exploring whether monetary policy statements (sentiment analysis using BERT transformer) could move government securities (G-secs) rate with less open market operations. Indian policy rates had not remained low commensurately with the United States interest rates post-global financial crisis. The fact that India‚Äôs G-secs rate is not falling as expected remains an open puzzle that we are actively trying to solve.

content:
This is a work in progress.
We are exploring why do manufacturing firms import intermediate inputs from multiple suppliers (even when the quality of the imported inputs remains the same)? Are they optimizing the hold-up problem, or are they diversifying risk? Is it dependent on the type of inputs they are importing? We found strong evidence of (product dependent) multiple sourcing even for small single-product firms from the Chinese Customs Data.
